title: Why is f injective if f(x) =f(x') and x=x'? - Quora

response.answer_text: f is not injective if “ f(x)=f(y) and x=y” f is injective if f(x)=f(y) IMPLIES x=y For example take f(x) = x^2 Suppose f(a) = f(b) Then, a^2 = b^2 But this does not imply a = b [ take a,b as 2,(-2) ] The point is that a function is injective if you can say for sure that if the function has the same value for two inputs than the the two inputs MUST be the same.
